bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, August 15, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] encloses his manuscript on yellow fever. He requests that Hutchison write letters of thanks on behalf of the College to the yellow fever informants. He discusses the logistics for Moran's travel.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, August 15, 1940
div1.p:
Herewith is the memorandum which I made as a result of my
trip. I hope that you can spend a couple of hours reading it. It will give
you a good background of knowledge concerning the whole yellow fever business.
Some of it, as you see, is confidential. None of it is to be published in this
form. I will appreciate knowing your present thoughts on the program. Do
you still want me to give an introductory talk on the conquest of yellow fever?
If you do, my idea was to have it illustrated with slides and make it as interest-
ing and popular as possible. Do you want any of the story published in any W.
and J. journal or shall I reserve that for my medical publication later? Should
I give the story at W. and J.? There is no purpose in spending any time at all
on the story for our search for the camp. So far as your audience is concerned,
that is completely unimportant, but sometime I want to talk to you about the
possibility that perhaps W. and J. and Columbia, and Johns Hopkins might join
together and raise money for a small memorial tablet on the Rojas farm if the
Cuban government goes ahead with its plan to build their memorial on the false
site. I have collected a number of historical as well as new photographs, some
of which I am enclosing. Would it be appropriate to have some of these framed
and hung on one of the walls in the Lazear Memorial Building, or would you prefer
to have the story written up and the photographs mounted on pages, and have it
bound and put in the library as a book?

I find that Dr. Finlay graduated from Jefferson College, Philadelphia,
1855. Does that make him in any way related to your college? I have not yet
gotten permission from the Department of Agriculture to have the poinciana wood
admitted to this country. If they will not let me bring it in, I will try to
have a few small objects made in Cuba, if you think that it would be nice to do
so. I will get a limb from a tree on the San Jose farm as near the site of the
camp as possible. I am trying to find the address of Walter Reed's daughter and
of Mrs. Lazear, but have not yet found them. Have you gotten Sawyer as the
speaker? Are you planning to invite Kissinger as well as Moran? General Kean
of Washington is, of course, as close friend to Walter Reed, and apparently the
government's historian of the yellow fever work. He is quite elderly, has a bad
stiff knee and a bad heart. Whether he should be invited or whether he would
accept, I do not know. Since you are praising Lazear and the American Board, the
presence of Finlay's son might be out of place.

May I suggest that you write the following letters to the following
people. It would help me much.

“Dear So and so: Dr. Jesse Lazear, a member of the U.S. Army Yellow
Fever Board, which discovered the cause of yellow fever, was an alumnus of this
college. This Fall, we are dedicating a memorial building in his name. At my
request, Dr. Philip Hench of the Mayo Clinic has been preparing a story on the
- 2 -
conquest of yellow fever. To re-tell not only the work of Lazear, of course,
but that of Dra. Finlay, Reed, Carroll, Agramonte, and all those connected with
this brilliant chapter in medical research. Dr. Hench has told me that in
connection with his investigations, you have been most helpful, and I wish,
as president of Washington and Jefferson College, my personal appreciation for
the help that you have already given him, and my hope that you may continue to
aid him in the re-telling of this story. We hope that he will be able to publish
at least some of his investigations and that we may have them, with photographs
of the people and places concerned, filed as a matter of permanent record, in
our Lazear Memorial Building.

Such a letter would help greatly, and I think should be sent to the
following:
Mr. John J. Moran, Avenida Menocal 455, Havana, Cuba.
Mr. John R. Kissinger, R. 8, Huntington, Indiana.
Mrs. Estella Agramonte Rodriguez-Leon, 311 Calle 15, Entre H e I,
Vedado, Havana.
Senora Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, 207 Calle 17, Vedado, Havana.
Mr. Luis Pogolotti, Cuba 3, Havana.
Gen. Albert E. Truby, 145 Laurel St., San Francisco.
Gen. J. R. Kean, 2804 N St. N.W., Washington, D. C.
Possibly also
Dr. Carlos E. Finlay, 25 No. 1075, Entre 4 c 6, Havana.
Dr. A. Diaz Albertini, Director, Finlay Institute, Havana, Cuba.

You will have received my check for $200.00 to be used in any way
you wish. If you want to use it to bring Moran, fine. But as I told you, before
I had a chance to tell Moran that the college would pay his expenses, he expressed
his appreciation of the invitation and said that he was sure he could get permission
from his boss to leave and thought that Mr. Pew might even be willing to pay his
expenses. It was his suggestion that you write to Mr. Pew, giving him the chance
to do so, with the idea that it would be sort of a nice advertisement for the
Sunoco Oil Co., to have its representative in a position of honor. If you do not
wish to tap Mr. Pew, use my check. This will cover all of Mr. Moran's expenses
including meals and stay in Washington, and might even give a little toward Mrs.
Moran's, but it hardly seems that we should have to pay her expenses, too. I think
he has enough money to be able to bring her himself.

The following is a letter which is my modification of one suggested by
Mr. Moran to be written to Mr. Pew: (Instead of composing one, I am sending you
his idea, but obviously it should be modified considerably, as he has made many
mistakes in it. I suggest that you modify Moran's last sentence. Perhaps if you
leave it out, Pew will offer to pay his way.)

General Reed; sthenson of Major Walter Reed, is living in Washington,
retired. I am writing him. I am sure that all he knows is second hand, as he was
but a child I believe at the time. If I find that he has some information, I will
ask you to write him also. Tell me again the date of the affair. I can't seem to
remember it. Let me know your final wishes as to whether you want me to talk and how
long.
